metadata.case_name: Four brothers (petitioners) v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Applicants are four brothers holding land in village Banat, tahsil Kairana, District Muzaffarnagar.
Notification issued under section 4 of the Act in respect of 223 villages in tahsil Kairana, declaring that the State Government had decided to make a scheme of consolidation in that area.
Necessary action under various provisions of the Act resulting in a statement of proposals under section 19.
Objections to these proposals filed by the petitioners and others, decided in April 1956.
Petitioners went in appeal to the Settlement Officer Consolidation, decided in August 1957.
Present petition filed in this Court thereafter.
U.P. Consolidation of Holdings Act, V of 1954, amended by U.P. Acts No. XXVI of 1954, No. XIII of 1955, No. XX of 1955, No. XXIV of 1956 and No. XVI of 1957.
Previous U.P. Consolidation of Holdings Act No. VIII of 1939, effective only if more than one-third proprietors applied.
Act passed by U.P. Legislature in 1953, assent of President on March 4, 1954, published March 8, 1954.
Declarations under section 4 made for major part of State including petitioners' village in July 1954.

In petitioners' case: in one chak, rental value Rs. 20-6-0 allotted Rs. 20-5-0; another chak Rs. 148-10-0 allotted Rs. 147-13-0; total land valued Rs. 169-0-0 allotted Rs. 168-2-0, loss Annas 0-14-0 (~0.5%).
Allahabad High Court held section 14(1)(ee) void under Article 31(2) pre-Fourth Amendment for no compensation; appeals pending.
Section 29-B enacted by Act XVI of 1957 with retrospective effect.

legal_issues.text: Section 6 read with section 4 gives arbitrary powers to State Government to accord discriminatory treatment to tenure-holders in different villages by placing some under consolidation while excluding others, offending Article 14.

Sections 8, 9 and 10 read with section 49 provide procedure for correction and revision of revenue records vitally different from that applicable to villages not under consolidation, discriminating under Article 14.

Sections 14 to 17 read with section 49 confer arbitrary powers on consolidation authorities to deprive tenure-holder of land or rights, depriving protection of courts available to others, discriminating under Article 14.
Sections 19 to 22 read with section 49 create discrimination on same grounds as sections 14 to 17, hit by Article 14.
Section 29-B provides inadequate compensation, hit by Article 31(2).

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 6 with s.4 arbitrary power to cancel declaration even for part of area, discriminates between villages under/not under consolidation.
Ss.8,9,10 with s.49 provide different procedure for records correction vs. U.P. Land Revenue Act, bars civil/revenue courts jurisdiction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; U.P. Land Revenue Act ss.40,41,51,54

petitioner_arguments.text: Ss.14-17 with s.49 arbitrary powers to deprive land/rights, no court protection.
Ss.19-22 with s.49 same discrimination as ss.14-17.
S.29-B inadequate compensation (not fair market value).

respondent_arguments.text: Section 6 is restatement of power under General Clauses Act; high status of State Government and rules remove arbitrariness.

court_reasoning.text: Even if s.6 invalid, severable, does not affect petitioners; leave open for appropriate case. Consolidation is boon, necessary for agriculture.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions severable; power of cancellation not inextricably mixed with ordering consolidation.

court_reasoning.text: Ch. II procedure (notice, hearing, evidence, one appeal) sufficient, expeditious for consolidation; rational classification with nexus to object; title disputes referred to arbitrator with Arbitration Act procedure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Difference justified as permissible classification for timely consolidation.

court_reasoning.text: Ch. III similar procedure (two hearings, arbitrator for title with finality, stays pending suits); necessary for timely scheme.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rational basis for classification with nexus to Act's object.

court_reasoning.text: Same as cr3 for statements of proposals.

S.29-B adequate: 4x hereditary rates for bhumidar, 2x for sirdar; small bits taken (~0.5-1%) consolidated for public purposes benefiting tenure-holders directly (e.g., pastures, schools); plus compact holdings advantage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cash + direct benefits = adequate compensation under Art.31(2) pre-Fourth Amendment.

holdings.text: Section 6 severable, issue left open; does not invalidate Act.
Ch. II procedure not discriminatory under Art.14.
Ch. III (ss.14-17,19-22) not discriminatory under Art.14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Allahabad High Court decisions on s.14(1)(ee)
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.14(1)(ee) void pre-s.29-B; appeals pending.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Consolidation of Holdings Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged provisions upheld as constitutional; scheme for consolidation operations.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14: no discrimination; Art.31(2): adequate compensation; Art.32: petition basis.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Land Revenue Act, 1901
statutes_cited.relevance: Ordinary procedure for records; contrasted with Act's expeditious procedure.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Applicable to arbitrator proceedings for title disputes.

outcome.summary: All challenges to constitutionality of U.P. Consolidation of Holdings Act dismissed; provisions upheld under Arts.14 and 31(2); Act is beneficial legislation for agriculture.

key_quotes.text: That consolidation would result in improving agricultural production goes without saying and it was with the object of encouraging the development of agriculture that consolidation schemes with a compulsory character were taken up in various States.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is in this setting that we have to examine the attack that has been made on the constitutionality of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Frames analysis considering Act's beneficial object.

key_quotes.text: The procedure that has been provided cannot by any means be said to be arbitrary or lacking in the essentials of principles of natural justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Taking into account the peculiar conditions in cases of this kind... it cannot be said that the cash compensation, added to the advantages which the tenure-holders get... is inadequate.
key_quotes.speaker: court
